comments.commentBody: So don't go to the Academy...

Congrats on the accomplishments of your family, but why should soccer be held to a standard that the multiibillion-dollar industries of college and pro football, basketball and pro baseball have never even tried to achieve?  The benefit is they got to play a great sport at a high level.  Period.  Unless it becomes their chosen career, there's no other need for it to "benefit society".

Put Brazil in a box and set it in a safe place 'cause there's no replicating that soccer culture. Aside from Brazil, there are other football powers who can produce results through the academy system. Can the U.S. be one of them? There's the rub. If the National team brain trust doesn't know anything more than dump and chase, long ball soccer instead of the possession short game that dominates at the highest level, than no system will produce results.

Soccer doesn't carry much cachet off the pitch. That's one reason its development lags football and basketball. It seems to me that any program to boost soccer here should take high-school sociology into account.

The day a homecoming queen's escort is a soccer player is the day we'll know soccer has "arrived."

Don't kids that play baseball or basketball in other countries aspire to play for the Yankees or Lakers and to emulate their idols?

You have to play for the best to be the best and right now the best league is in England. History has shown this will change within the coming decade, but as of now, its far superior to anywhere else.

Hopefully one day players will aspire to play for a MLS team as their pinnacle, but today is not that day.

Because the physical damage players suffer and how the sport only has one route of entry (collegiate football), you'll never see it applied to American football.  Basketball though is very likely to adopt an academy system, though high school basketball often doesn't experience as much a talent gap as soccer does.  (5 starters vs 11)
Please elaborate on how it will deprive them of their childhood

Sue, what on earth are you talking about?
Unlimited substitutions would slow the game down. Every other minute a new player would be introduced and bring the game down to a crawl. I assume you want the clock to count down too?

As for the diving, I hope you haven't seen any Packers or Oregon football game recently, where their opponents mysteriously went down with magical injuries. That culture you speak of is in every sport, it's only noticed more in soccer because it happens around the ball.
Why care if US wins gold medals at the Olympics then?  I find it funny too that you hail from a place where one of America's best soccer players is from.

Colt, Seattle: Outdated? I see it all around me, as my two young soccer-playing kids approach this age of insanity.

USSF seems to say that the elite club itself pays a nominal fee to opt in to the academy program, but the players on these teams would still need to shell out considerable dues and travel expenses, no?

Better for kids to play everyday in the backyard with friends, also with adults who can play, just like sandlot baseball and shooting hoops, or having a catch with Dad.

Just as our Big-3 players are formed at young ages, so are the best soccer players formed around the world: FIRST through disorganized play and FUN.

Then the VERY best get picked up at 13–16 by professional clubs. You can't manufacture that kind of talent, and it develops through 20 hrs. of unorganized ball-on-the-foot a week, and playing with grandpa too . . . as Klinsmann said. Not through organized stuff.

. . . and certainly not through overparenting or overpaid soccer factories. We went wrong when parents started to think they understood player development -- a little knowledge is a dangerous thing -- and they are easily misled by the soccer "industry."

Pro teams must operate the same as big-time clubs the world round and must pluck young talent where they find it, paying for that talent, not vice versa.

For everyone but that Red Bull recruit: Play high school soccer! It's part of the FUN and the excitement and . . . it's FREE! Or at least a good use of tax payer dollars.
Bell, you do realize that the Academy plan is built to prevent burnout and injuries right?

1. But what use is identifying a talent when he cannot achieve a high level? We can point out kids with potential, but in the end training is what makes that potential into actual talent. Both must be taken hand-in-hand

2. If he wants to play for his HS, I'm sure USSF would let him, he just can't be a part of the accredited academies until the soccer year is up, and then he would have to try out for the academies again. There will probably be several non-USSF academies that roll out a program for kids to play HS.
How are you determining the number of players coming out of the academies? It's a 4 year program and has been in existence for about 4 years...
I must say I laughed out loud, no self-respecting LFC supporter would say they love the "Liverpool Reds."
This is an absurd "comparison".

Here's how the system works - the USSF has published guidelines for the Development Academy program and what each DA team's training objectives should be. See: http://www.ussoccer.com/Teams/Development-Academy/Academy-Overview.aspx.

Every MLS team has committed to establishing at least one club-sponsored DA program. So, in each metro area with an MLS team, there's an MLS DA. http://academy.demosphere.com/. These teams are designed to feed players into their own MLS teams, or, in some cases, the national team. See: Juan Agudelo.

If a high school kid wants to play club soccer, he can try out for a DA spot, for a spot at a different "premier" team, try out for his high school team, or even just play good ol' pickup.

Bell, you continue to service your ignorance.  No one is forcing anyone to do anything.  The players have options and what they do is their choice.  And USSF does service the millions of kids you mention, but what's the best way to do that I must ask?  Should they charge these millions of kids, or become an international power by winning global tournaments, getting sponsors who in turn help lower these costs for these kids to play, helping with the installation of better fields, facilities and coaching education and giving the millions of kids who you believe are getting denied, a greater opportunity to play soccer.  So you have options too, a lez affair which does nothing to further the game in America, or something like the academy system to get more money flowing into the sport in America.
And who profits if they stay in school, oh those coaches that charge them thousands of dollars to play for a poorly setup travel team.  Either way, someone is profiting from their decision.

How are you reaching these conclusions? The new DA program (see: http://www.ussoccer.com/Teams/Development-Academy/Academy-Overview.aspx) actually counters the concepts of play more and win more at all costs, and replaces it with skill- and training-focused operations.

Are you sure that most players of MLS soccer cannot tell them difference between a system and a style of play? (Your introductory claim - reread it.) That's pretty sweeping, no?

As for most of the futbol powers not having elite schooled players, what about the vaunted Ajax, Barcelona, and Manchester United academies, not to mention those found at just about every Premier League, La Liga, Serie A, and Bundesliga team? Giggs, Scholes, and Beckham all played together as youths in the Man U system. Most of the current Barcelona lineup (including Argentinian Lionel Messi) played together as youngsters at Camp Nou. Maybe those aren't futbol powers?
The same could be said for Julliard or the New York High School for the Arts.

For those who think that high school students are being deprived and that they're being sold a bill of goods, please remember that this only applies to athletes choosing to take the chance to be the best.  I will remind you that all over America high school students transfer to stronger teams to be able to catch the eye of college coaches so they can compete for scholarships (all of this has huge financial implications) for the statistically miniscule chance of becoming a pro football, basketball, hockey etc player.  That's how you make it to the top level folks.  Whats not nearly important is that high school teams be as strong as they could be.  In a sense, if the top players are on Academy teams, you actually end up creating opportunities for more populous, but less talented student athletes who will no only be able to make teams they might not otherwise have, but will also have a real chance at real minutes.  There are no losers here folks, as this is all voluntary.  Having played club and school at that age, I speak from experience as I'm sure others do.  My Div 1 college career didn't suffer, but I would have loved to see how good I could've been.  I'll never know, but these kids will find out if they have what it takes.  Good for them!

Since when is America supposed to be like the rest of the world?  Aren't we the ones supposed to be exceptional?  To deprive a kid from his or her High School scholastic soccer experience is truly a shame...especially when it is done under the reasons argued by USSF.  It also deprives lower income talent whose only opportunity is High School soccer.  As for the rest of the world....just be glad some of our professional MLB, NFL, or NBA athletes don't play soccer.

I have two sons playing for the San Jose Earthquakes Academy teams.  Neither will play high school soccer.  Both these boys want to play soccer in college.  The Academy is the best way to be seen and recruited by college coaches.  It has been estimated that 80% of today's college players come from the Academy system.  I have talked to several college coaches and they don't attend high school games... they go to major tournaments (Surf Cup, Dallas Cup) and Academy matches to find their recruits.  That is a simple fact of life.  With a few exceptions the high school teams are a mixture of player skills.  The elite players get frustrated on high school teams and the injuries are greater (in my experience) at the high school level than on the Academy teams.  If you are really good in high school you will get hacked.  Second, the Academy teams get top rate coaching.  High school coaching is inconsistent at best.  So, if you want to compete at the highest level, get recruited by a good college and play in a D1 program you play on an Academy team.  If you want to make the local newspaper and be a BMOC, then play high school soccer and hope that you don't get your ACL blown out..

Aaron, well said, can't deny any of your points, but remember that there are several potential paths to success in soccer in the US. The diamonds in the rough (Carlos Tevez, etc) of our society have options, too.

How many people criticizing the acadamies watch, follow, and are really passionate about soccer? It's easy to condemn a system, for a sport they don't have a lot of interest in.

Besides the majority of players won't join the acadamies. They will be apart of their high school teams. This development system will only affect a small group of elite players, who love the game they play. There will still be a strong high school soccer infastructure, which has its benefits. It won't go away as a result of acadamies.
